data.title: This Day in History For August 5
data.text:
1861 – US Army abolished flogging.

1905 – First meeting of the Russian and Japanese peace commissioners takes place in President Theodore Roosevelt’s home at Oyster Bay, New York.

1914 – United States and Nicaragua sign treaty granting canal rights to the United States.

1917 – The entire US National Guard is taken into national service, subject to presidential rather than state control.

1921 – KDKA Pittsburgh presents first radio broadcast of Major League Baseball with Harold Arlin calling play-by-play as the Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies 8-5.

1936 – American athlete Jesse Owens wins 200-meter race in world record time of 20.7 seconds to win his third gold medal of the Berlin Olympics.

1944 – United States troops occupy Vannes, Brittany during World War II.

1953 – “From Here to Eternity,” based on the book by James Jones, directed by Fred Zimmerman and starring Burt Lancaster, Montgomery Clift and Frank Sinatra, is released. It wins an Academy Award for Best Picture in 1954.

1957 – Comic strip “Andy Capp” makes its debut.

1963 – Britain, United States and Soviet Union sign nuclear test ban treaty.

1964 – United States begins bombing North Vietnam in response to the real and imagined attacks on US Navy ships in the Gulf of Tonkin.

1967 – Bobby Gentry releases her only hit “Ode to Billy Joe.”

1972 – Detroit Tigers shortstop Ed Brinkman commits an error, ending a record streak of 72 games and 331 total chances without a misplay.

1981 – President Ronald Reagan fires 11,500 striking air traffic controllers.

1989 – NASA Venus probe Magellan launched from Space shuttle.

1997 – Ramzi Yousef, mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing in 1993, goes on trial.

2005 – NBA announces Las Vegas will host the 2007 All Star game, becoming the first time the event will be held in a city without an NBA team.

2012 – Gunman opens fire on Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wisconsin, killing six people and committing suicide.

2022 – Jury in Austin, Texas decides “Infowars” host Alex Jones should pay $45.2 million in punitive damages to parents of Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting victims due to his promotion of false conspiracy theories that the massacre was a hoax.

2022 – Volkswagen launches a prototype of its first flying car, an automated, electric passenger vehicle nicknamed “Flying Tiger.”
